column1: 21:01|He figured he’d start her out with an exceptionally American meal: cheeseburgers
column4: Coke. He’d get a pie for dessert: apple. He’d top it off with ice cream and watch as she squirmed and squealed. When she finished
column5: he’d lift her from her chair
column7: kiss every inch. They’d have sex all night
column9:
he wouldn’t pay.
He looked at his watch—9:01 P.M.|Reprieve|James Han Mattson

column1: 21:01|It was past nine. William had finished his homework and his supper. Once he had said good night to his parents and Mrs. Phillips
column2: he crept upstairs to the attic with the two bugs
column4: and his magnifying glass. He wanted to take a closer look at the token.|The Castle in the Attic|Elizabeth Winthrop

column1: 21:01|On the evening before K.'s thirty-first birthday - it was about nine o'clock
column2: when there is a lull in the streets - two gentlemen came to his apartment.|The Trial|Franz Kafka

column1: 21:01|The good Brants did not allow the boys to play out after nine in summer evenings; they were sent to bed at that hour; Eddie honorably remained
column2: but Georgie usually slipped out of the window toward ten
column3: and enjoyed himself until midnight.|Edward Mills and George Benton: A Tale|Mark Twain

column1: 21:01|Billy Weaver had travelled down from London on the slow afternoon train
column2: with a change at Swindon on the way
column3: and by the time he got to Bath it was about nine o’clock in the evening and the moon was coming up out of a clear starry sky over the houses opposite the station entrance. But the air was deadly cold and the wind was like a flat blade of ice on his cheeks.|The Landlady|Roald Dahl
